name: Minotar
author: Luke Strickland and Joel Bergroth

sections.description:
Minotar gives you the option to replace the default avatars found in WordPress with Minecraft avatars. The API used is found at http://minotar.net and can be used freely by anyone.

The avatars is taken from the Minecraft equivalent of users and comment posters, if a commenter uses the name Herobrine on a comment the skin of Herobrine in Minecraft is used as an avatar.

Note: The avatars are case-sensitive. Eg: notch and Notch are different names.

Features:

  • Minecraft avatars for commenters and users
  • BuddyPress support
sections.installation:
1. Upload the ‘minotar-minecraft-avatars’ folder to the ‘/wp-content/plugins/’ directory
  2. Activate the plugin through the ‘Plugins’ menu in WordPress
sections.faq:
Where can I get support?

You can get support at #axxim on irc.esper.net

How do I change the avatars back?

Either you change the default avatar in Settings – Discussion on the admin panel or you just delete the plugin.
sections.changelog:
1.6

  • Fixed: WordPress changed the way to get the active user

1.5

  • Added: BuddyPress support (tested on version 1.5.3.1)

1.4

  • Added: A changelog for 1.3 that I forgot

1.0

  • Added: Deletes all traces of plugin when uninstalled.
  • Fixed: When deactivating or deleting the plugin the last used avatar is reenabled
  • Fixed: Minotars are shown in the Discussion page
  • Plugin is rewritten for maintainability and stability

0.2

  • Added: Minotar setting to the Settings – Discussion page
  • Added: Automatically changes the default avatar to Minotar on plugin activation
  • Added: Automatically changes back to mystery man on plugin deactivation/uninstallation
  • Added: Now avatars of users are changed aswell
  • Fixed: Avatars should now be shown in correct size no matter what page they’re displayed in
  • Fixed: Minotar does not replace all other avatar examples in the Discussion page

0.1

  • Initial release

short_description: Minotar enables the use of Minecraft avatars in WordPress.
